bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Arthur W. Packard, December 5, 1947

div1.p: Hench thanks Packard for meeting with him in New York. He reports that the Reed Memorial Association has reaffirmed its commitment to memorialize Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Arthur W. Packard, December 5, 1947
div1.opener:
December 5, 1947
Mr. Arthur W. Packard
30 Rockefeller Plaza
New York 20, New York
My dear Mr. Packard:
div1.p:
I have just returned from my eastern trip. Permit me to thank
you sincerely once more for your courtesy in seeing me. I fully realize that
innumerable requests for financial help come to you and I fully understand the
necessity for you to follow certain policies.

I did not mean to “put you on the spot” by asking for your advice
as to who might help me. I, admitedly, am a complete amateur in trying to
raise funds for any venture and I meant to ask you for general advice and did
not mean to ask you for specific names of possible donors.

The day after I saw you, I was in Washington at the meeting of the
Board of Managers of the Walter Reed Memorial Association. This Board has
previously approved my plan to memorialize the little Cuban spot. I reopened
the question and asked them to reconsider it in a very realistic fashion,
stating that perhaps we might better let nature take its course and let the
little building disappear, but it was the unanimous opinion of the Board that
we should continue our efforts to memorialize the spot and this we will do.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
